title: Zelenskiy: Ukraine, US working on economic deal to...
body:
Feb 21 (Reuters) -

Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said on Friday that officials from his country and the U.S. were working on concluding an economic deal to ensure that the accord worked and was fair to Kyiv.

In Washington, U.S. President Donald Trump said negotiators were close to clinching an accord.

Zelenskiy rejected an initial proposal focusing on cooperation around metals, saying it was "not a serious conversation" and not in Ukraine's interests.

"Today, the teams of Ukraine and the United States are working on a draft agreement between our governments," Zelenskiy said in his nightly video address.

"This agreement has the potential to strengthen our relations and, most importantly, the details must be arranged in such a way that ensures it works. I am hoping for a result, a fair result."

Zelenskiy's comments followed a conversation between his chief of staff, Andrii Yermak, and U.S. National Security Advisor Mike Waltz. The Ukrainian president's office said the two men discussed "aligning positions" in bilateral relations.

Yermak "stressed the importance of maintaining bilateral cooperation and a high level of relations between Ukraine and the United States", according to the president's office.

Waltz said on Friday he expected Zelenskiy to sign the minerals agreement with the U.S. as part of efforts to end the Ukraine war.

"Here's the bottom line, President Zelenskiy is going to sign that deal, and you will see that in the very short term," Waltz told the Conservative Political Action Conference on the outskirts of Washington.

Zelenskiy rejected U.S. demands for $500 billion in mineral wealth from Ukraine to repay Washington for wartime aid, saying the U.S. had supplied nowhere near that sum.

He also said the proposed deal offered none of the security guarantees that Ukraine is seeking as part of a peace settlement.

Zelenskiy became involved in barbed exchanges with Trump this week over approaches to a peace settlement and the opening of U.S.-Russian talks to which Ukraine was not invited.

Trump branded the Ukrainian leader "a dictator without elections," a reference to Zelenskiy remaining in office beyond his mandate without calling a wartime election.

In his address, Zelenskiy provided details of telephone calls he made to European and African leaders -- including Croatia, the Czech Republic, Germany, Slovenia, Ireland, Luxembourg and Sweden.

"The main conclusion is that Europe must and can do considerably more so that peace can realistically be achieved," he said. (Reporting by Yuliia Dysa; Editing by Alison Williams, Ron Popeski and David Gregorio)

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Volodymyr Zelenskiy as Ukraine's President and quotes him, confirming both his name and the exact description.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy" and refers to him as the Ukrainian president. The Wikidata entity is Volodymyr Zelenskyy, President of Ukraine since 2019. The spelling difference is a common transliteration variation, and the context (role as president, mention of Kyiv, and reference to his office) matches the Wikidata description and occupation list. No other individual with a similar name is discussed, so the entity is confidently identified.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Zelenskiy is quoted multiple times in the article, both in his nightly video address and in the text. The article contains direct quotations attributed to him, confirming that he is making statements.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the President of Ukraine to speak publicly about economic agreements with the United States, to reject proposals, and to discuss diplomatic relations. The statements align with his official role and responsibilities.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the article content and the Wikidata profile. The only minor discrepancy is the transliteration of the surname, which is acceptable.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "U.S. President Donald Trump" in the sentence: "In Washington, U.S. President Donald Trump said negotiators were close to clinching an accord." This confirms the target entity is present and identified as the U.S. President.
reasoning.statement_detection: The same sentence attributes a direct statement to Donald Trump: "said negotiators were close to clinching an accord." This is a clear instance of the entity making a declarative statement.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Among the provided candidates, Q22686 (Donald Trump) matches the name, the title of U.S. President, and the context of the statement. The other candidates (Donald Trump Jr., a physician Donald Trump, and Donald Trump III) do not hold the presidential office or are unrelated to the context. Therefore Q22686 is the sole viable match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q22686 holds the position of President of the United States (2025‑present) and is the appropriate authority to make statements about U.S. negotiations with Ukraine. The statement aligns with the official capacity of the U.S. President.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the U.S. President to comment on the progress of a bilateral economic agreement with Ukraine. The statement is consistent with the role and typical public communications of a sitting president.
reasoning.final_justification: The target entity is present in the article, is making a statement, and the only candidate that fits the name, title, and context is Q22686. All critical identification and attribution factors are satisfied.

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Andrii Yermak as Zelenskiy's chief of staff, confirming both his name and his role as a non‑elected government official.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Andrii Yermak" as "Zelenskiy's chief of staff" and references his role in a conversation with U.S. National Security Advisor Mike Waltz. This matches the Wikidata entity’s position as Head of the Office of the President of Ukraine (chief of staff) and the description "Zelenskiy's chief of staff". No other individual named Andrii Yermak is mentioned, and the contextual details (role, affiliation with the Ukrainian presidency) align perfectly with the Wikidata profile.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Yermak is reported to have made statements: "Yermak 'stressed the importance of maintaining bilateral cooperation and a high level of relations between Ukraine and the United States', according to the president's office." The attribution is clear (president's office) and the content is a direct quote attributed to Yermak.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the chief of staff of the Ukrainian president to comment on bilateral cooperation with the United States, especially in the context of a high‑level negotiation. The statement aligns with Yermak’s official capacity and the political context described.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions were found between the article’s depiction of Yermak and the Wikidata entity’s profile.

reasoning.statement_detection: Waltz is directly quoted: "Here's the bottom line, President Zelenskiy is going to sign that deal, and you will see that in the very short term," and the article states he said this on Friday. Thus, he is making statements in the article.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q55386653 lists "United States National Security Advisor" as a position held from 2025‑01‑20 to 2025‑05‑01, which aligns with the article’s date (Feb 21, 2025). The name matches exactly, and the role matches the target description. Candidate Q95813934 is an actor with no relevant position, so it is excluded.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q55386653 holds the official post of U.S. National Security Advisor during the time of the article, giving him the authority to make the statements attributed to him.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the National Security Advisor to comment on U.S.–Ukraine mineral agreements and to speak at a political conference, as described in the article.
reasoning.final_justification: The entity "Mike Waltz" is present in the article, is making statements, and the best matching Wikidata candidate is Q55386653, which satisfies all identification and attribution criteria.
